title: Thursday, 4th October 2018
bodyHTML:
Blank canvas good morning everyone
11:05 am
BE11:05am

Morning! Hello, hey there, hi. This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's etc

Otter Hello Thursday friends
Manxish Morning all
BE11:05am

Did anyone notice I called yesterday's session Tuesday? Possibly not.

GBKrona Hola
BE11:06am

Here at AV know what time it is. But not necessarily what day.

11:06 am
BE11:06am

Anyway, you see this?

Jimmeh So it's finally all over for bond markets....?
Grouchmonkey Morgen
BE11:06am

https://ftalphavil...-chief-cartoonist/

Soundbuy Morgen
BE11:07am

Everyone will have their own favourite. This is mine

11:07 am
BE11:07am

BE11:08am

Which coincidentally is what we have today.

Imperial Goldsmith Kingfisher? Northern Trust pushing the SOTP thesis again makes one think that “Trian 1” has their one in its crosshairs
BornCynic Morning
BE11:09am

r u risk off?

11:10 am
BE11:10am

treasury yields bare ......... whatever. I'm not going to embarrass myself by claiming I know youthspeak

BornCynic After reading Mr Schiller's recent Guardian article - risk off.
BE11:12am

So .... we have FTSE down 1% or so as Treasuries and the dollar shunt higher, without any specific catalyst (though lots of longer view nagging concerns, of course, before you point them out ROTR).

PBateman Morning
nightingale20201 morning
BE11:14am

SG incoming.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Actually, not SG .... Have Panmure instead.

BE11:15am

With the US ten-year Treasury yield hitting their highest level since 2014 there is understandable angst on how quick and how damaging a bond market unwind can be. Our view is that much of the structural demand for long-dated income remains intact, whilst the paucity of yields available in other developed markets will limit the upside risk. The transmission of higher yields into the real US economy remains modest with 30-year mortgages available at 4.75% and AAA-rated debt at 4.0%:

BE11:15am

It is our view that long-dated Treasuries have to reach 4.0-5.0% before the transmission to lower growth and corporate earnings sets in. We outlined this view in: “IS A BOND MARKET SELL-OFF SET TO ROUT EQUITIES? NOT SO FAST”: (Panmure Gordon; Feb 2018). In particular the most recent moves have largely been to nominal yields as inflationary pressure builds – there has been little pressure on real yields that remain around +0.5% at the long end of the Treasury curve.

GEMS Trader EM's getting hit. Any contrarians out there?
11:16 am
BE11:16am

BE11:17am

Which is off the back of Panmure's Q4 outlook, the gist of which is ....

BE11:17am

The headline is that whilst the global expansion remains intact, the
lack of spare capacity now available in developed markets is generating a series of “end-of-cycle” risks. We note that recent comments from FOMC members Powell and Evans reaffirms our view that the Fed is largely relaxed about the forward pace of monetary tightening. The justification for this stance looks a lot like late-cycle hubris triggering the belief that monetary policy can chase the unemployment rate lower without being inflationary. Whilst we have some sympathy with this view - given the structural challenges to US wage growth (creeping digitisation, global price arbitrage, weak unionization) - this is not without risk. It strengthens our view that the risk of a policy mistake that derails global growth sits at a multi-year high.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Couple of other things to share before we move on.

BE11:18am

Citi saying the rates selloff "seems to have been triggered by a break of the
closely watched 3.25% level in 30y rates, which set off technical alarm bells for
some investors."

BE11:19am

Technical alarm bells. They're the worst type.

11:19 am
BE11:20am

Over the last couple of weeks, Treasuries have failed to rally even on bullish developments, suggesting at least some bull fatigue. For example, this week, 10y BTP-Bund spreads widened out to 300bp, yet Treasuries did not rally. Low inflation prints have not been enough to give a bid to bonds. Domestic data has continued to be strong, but are mostly meeting already bullish expectations (the Citi surprise indices continue to tread water). Today’s ADP release did come in higher than expectations and given that the sell-off took place after the release, we think that expectations of a blockbuster payrolls report on Friday are also playing a role in the selloff.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian I'm contrarian planet Earth! ;)
PBateman Ted Baker please
Jimmeh Higher tsy yields. Turkey, Italy et al in meltdown. No sir! EM's are heading south.
BE11:21am

They're ..... fine, relatively.

PeterC Morning, anything on DFS please? Weak sales from May-July pushed into 2019 fin year. Quite a contrast to SCS figs
BE11:22am

On valuations, we find the market attractive, while we admit that sentiment may be bearish on Treasuries. We plan to add to our longs if we get closer to the 3.20-3.25% in 10y Treasuries. In the near term, risks to keep an eye on are: mortgage convexity hedging (swap spreads tightened today suggesting that it wasn’t a factor today), continued selling by trend following funds/ CTAs and a much stronger payrolls report (today’s selloff already anticipates a stronger than consensus report of 180K payrolls growth and 2.8% AHE).

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian @BE "called yesterday's session Tuesday" - yes I did. Your working week suddenly got one day shorter - lucky you!
11:22 am
undefined
BE11:23am

Okay, stocks wise ............ Ted Baker's as good a place to start as any, since it's requested.

Ted Baker PLC (TED:LSE): Last: 2,078, down 230 (-9.97%), High: 2,198, Low: 1,979, Volume: 394.75k
11:23 am
BE11:24am

Interims. Bad. High street problems countering any possible positive.

BE11:24am

At the headline, PBT growth of 3.5% looks fine.

Tom Dalgleish TED just another main street shop now
BE11:25am

But guidance is pretty gloomy so consensus is heading lower.

11:25 am
BE11:26am

Weather gets the blame, inevitably, as does House of Fraser

BE11:26am

Consensus for the full-year was £81m at the PBT level. That's likely to come back by about 5%.

BE11:27am

Share price reaction is because a valuation of 15 times 2019 doesn't price in downgrades, no matter how many mitigating factors there are.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

Here's Goldman with the number soup.

Tom Dalgleish My TED leather belt proved to be plasticised on one side which separated away in 2 weeks
BE11:28am

1H19 PBT £25.0mn, +3.5% yoy (GSe £25.1mn), with cFX revenues of
+5.5% (GSe +6.5%), split Retail cFX +2.9% and Wholesale +12.8% (GSe +3.5% and +14%).
Retail cFX sales +2.9% (GSe +3.5%), driven by space +4.6%, LFL -1.7% (GSe
space +4.6%, LFL -1.1%). By geography Retail cFX sales split, UK and Europe retail sales cFX +0.7% (GSe +1.7%), North America +8.1% (GSe +8.6%) and MEAAA +1.8% (GSe +3.1%). 1H19 cFX Wholesale sales +12.8% (GSe +14%).
Gross margins -60bps (GSe -46bps), with retail gross margin -140bps due to higher promotional activity, offset in part by wholesale margins (+320bps) given a higher proportion of sales to tustee partners (vs retail licence partners). Combined with opex/sales -20bp, this drove EBIT margins -40bp to 8.5% (GSe -30bps).

BE11:28am

FY19 guidance: - Wholesale revenue growth ‘mid to high single digits’ cFX from ‘high single digit’ (GSe +10%)

11:28 am
BE11:29am

Yes, but what does it all mean, Goldman?

BE11:29am

What does it all mean? Other things equal, the lower top line guidance would imply FY19 PBT Bloomberg consensus revision of c.-4% to -6% or c. £76-£77mn (EPS 133-135p, +4-6% yoy). This assumes FY19 cFX Retail sales c.+4%LFL +1% (from +5.5%+2.5%), Wholesale sales c.+8% (from +10%).
Valuation: Our 12-month price target of 2,920p is DCF derived and equates to a 15.6x FY20E EV/EBIT multiple.

Dorian Gray are ted's grooming room barbers part of ted baker plc?
BE11:30am

We've suggested before that Goldman research often seems to be written by robots for robots. I'm only 51% certain that's a joke.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

(@Dorian: yep. And I'm not overly keen, FWIW.)

BE11:31am

Peel Hunt still write for people, thankfully.

Dorian Gray @BE neither! over-priced, inauthentic 'turkish' experience
BE11:32am

With a warm start to autumn, current apparel sales remain challenging, something Ted won’t be immune to, albeit comparatives ease as we move into October. We are trimming our full-year estimates by c4% or £3m to £76.5m, 133.9p.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Add on weakness. Ted continues to offer attractive medium-term prospects. The business benefits from a small, flexible own store estate; while store-only LFL sales have suffered, the combined Retail platform continues to show growth and Ted generates attractive margins on e-commerce sales. Trading on 16x PER, we would see weakness as an opportunity to Add.

BE11:33am

And Barclays, more cautious

nichoman @Dorian - i had a bit of a miserable experience at the barbers recently. painfully slow and really grumpy barber.
BE11:33am

Ted Baker’s 1H was somewhat disappointing, but we don’t think this should come as a major surprise given the P1 trading update provided in June (which covered 19 of the 28 weeks in 1H). Retail in particular has been challenged, and has witnessed sluggish sales growth, margin weakness and a sequential slowdown in e-commerce growth – which the company has largely attributed to external factors.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

On the other hand, the wholesale channel is holding up well - with sales on track to meet [or even potentially exceed] FY guidance and margins benefiting from partner mix. All in all, the company missed our 1H PBT estimates by c2% (no consensus available) and looks less likely to meet FY guidance for the bottom end of the +10-15% PBT growth range [we are already below this at +8.2%]. This is certainly disappointing – especially since we had already lowered our FY estimates previously - but we would be cautious about extrapolate too much from it given challenging market conditions. Ultimately, Ted Baker has a strong brand with meaningful whitespace and a sensible rollout out trajectory – and it trades on what we view as a meaningful but justifiably premium vs. retail peers [c18x CY19 EPS vs. c13x]. We are Equal Weight.

undefined
alewis2005 Many many hipster barbers around Shoreditch that happily charge £50+ a cut because they also offer you a whiskey while they're at it. I found a chap who'll do it in 15 mins, charge you £16, and not talk to you while he's doing it. Fantastic.
Soundbuy @ alewis2005 - take a hip flask for the full hipster experience..........
BE11:37am

(ROTR: as someone who's finding increasingly that they have to pay for a search party rather than a barber, my recommendations can't be relied upon. But the Ted's Grooming experience was really not for me. I side with @alewis's view here.)

Jimmeh When you are as follically challenged as I am, anything over £15 including tip makes the blood boil!
11:37 am
BE11:37am

Okay, what else?

Jimmeh Though what any of this has to do with global markets and economics beats me. Maybe I'm on the wrong site or something...
Blank canvas Ocado? (no holding in it, just curious)
BE11:38am

Did you catch this? Bloomberg wrap on Balkans funny money: https://www.bloomb...anske-bank-scandal

Puntino Baltics, surely?
BE11:39am

Involving some very, very big numbers.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

Swedbank instantly sold off in response, as a lot of people apparently realised somewhat belatedly that it's Estonia's biggest non-domestic bank,

Shinshin If you travel to the other side of both the Central line and the Levant, the going rate around Edgware Rd for a regular cut is a tenner to the house and whatever you want to the barber. And excellent arabic tea.
Manxish That Bloomberg article on the (possibly Chinese) hacking of various US companies and Govt agencies was also very interesting
BE11:41am

Did I say Baltics?!? I meant Balkans. Sorry, brain fried. See also Tuesday-Wednesday confusion ....

BE11:42am

Or rather, the opposite. Deary me. Right .... Anyway .....

11:42 am
BE11:42am

Here's JP Morgan, who's seen enough.

BE11:42am

The latest statement from the Estonian Central Bank continues to draw attention to
the Swedish banks given their dominant market share. According to the statement,
over $1trn of cross border money flowed through the small Baltic country in
2008-15. With 1) Swedbank having a 55% deposit market share in Estonia (nonresident
deposits peaked at c.20% of total deposits in the country); 2) the bank
engaging with some, although “limited number” of non-resident customers in the
Baltics; 3) c.6%/7% of total deposits in Estonia/Latvia being in USD; 4) Baltics
accounting for over 20% of Swedbank’s net income; and 5) Swedbank having a
US New York State-licensed branch, we feel that the valuation at the current level
is fair and downgrade Swedbank to N (from OW) pending further clarification.
We keep our EPS unchanged and cut our Dec19E PT to SEK210 (from SEK240)
on a lower PE multiple for the Baltics. Trading at 10x PE, 1.7x PNAV for a
17.6% RoNAV in 2020e, we believe Swedbank is fairly priced. Given the
downgrade, we take Swedbank out of our top pick European bank portfolio.

Blank canvas BE: you need to retire to your corner and sit on a three legged stool while someone fans you
A. M. @alewis2005: lack of talk (beyond the essentials) is a major plus.
BE11:43am

Swedbank had a conference call yesterday on the Bloomberg report. JPM wasn't terribly reassured.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

The call was a disappointment, in our view, as it was short (less than 10min) and didn’t provide any details on Swedbank’s Baltic non-resident business. Whilst not all cross border transactions or non-resident flows are suspicious, Danske said that most of their €200bn flows (predominantly in USD and EUR) they saw over 2007-15 seemed suspicious. Danske also said they held a 44% market share in non-resident deposits in Estonia, which leaves the question mark around who accommodated the remaining 56%. The Nordic banks have an aggregated c.95% market share in Estonia, with Swedbank having the largest with a 55% deposit market share.

BE11:45am

Yeah, when a fifth of your earnings come from the Baltics (but definitely not the Balkans, to be clear) you probably need to do a bit more than ten minutes of chat to shore up confidence.

BE11:46am

The counterpoint is set out be Jefferies ....

11:46 am
BE11:47am

Swedbank's SEK 14.3bn ($1.6bn) of market cap loss yesterday, for what
the Estonian Central Bank clarified may potentially just be helping local
entrepreneurs facilitate the sale of milk to Lithuania, seems slightly excessive to us. Swedbank, peer + SFSA reassurance over limited money-laundering risks, controls & the size of NRPs should help to remove the overhang on the shares from this issue, with the market fretting over a Danske-Estonia episode rerun.

G. H. @blank canvas: +1 for Ocado
BE11:48am

Course, mentions of milk production and alleged organised crime brings to mind .....

BE11:48am

11:48 am
BE11:48am

... but we have to take this seriously. Back to Jefferies.

BE11:49am

Sept 21, Swedbank's CEO told investors that its leading market share in Estonia was precisely the reason they were largely unfazed by the issues currently confronting Danske. Running a full banking operation in Estonia. where it's half the market and has a full suite of products, is different from just running a non-resident portfolio, where risks/oversight are different. The CEO noted Swedbank had worked with US banks, given their expertise in this area vs Nordic peers, the FIU + the FSA in the Baltics on KYC and AML over the last decade. And in a message that was reiterated yesterday by the lender in response to the press report, the CEO said Swedbank had continually been reviewing KYC in light of everchanging regulation, as well as the Danske case.

Excel Developer thanks for US Treasuries grey @BE
FS SPI LN - another downgrade today...

Hang on, I'm just going to screenshot this because it refuses to cut and paste.

Flaneur Informed yesterday (after show) that the Royal Mail stories were timed to coincide with the end of an employee embargo on selling shares.Get the drop in ahead of the staff and hope they'll hold on for a while longer is the jist...
Flaneur *When I say 'coincide' I mean 'preempt'.
BE11:58am

Been hearing similar things for the bet part of a year, and noted the suggestions here many many times. Nevertheless, it seems to be a name that's in the minds of the warmer traders once again.

11:58 am
undefined
Blue horseshoe... Re GNC..Pret was bought for £1.5bn
BE11:59am

As for Spire .......... Jefferies this time.

FS Anything new on Spire Healthcare?
BE11:59am

Only six months post April's CMD, and Spire’s 2022 targets already look ambitious. Overhyped self-pay, while growing high s.d., looks unlikely to deliver 14% CAGR especially given the lack of presence in Central London (40% of the private market). Meanwhile, budget cuts at NHS and looming Brexit threaten NHS and PMI businesses leaving too large a gap to fill with high s.d. of targeted cost saves in ‘19E. Downgrade to Underperform with 115p PT.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

(@Blue: what on earth does that have to do with the price of a baguette? One's retail, the other's wholesale.)

Spire Healthcare Group PLC (SPI:LSE): Last: 138.00, down 8.8 (-5.99%), High: 142.20, Low: 133.00, Volume: 3.02m
BE12:00pm

Spire's 2022 targets look increasingly ambitious: At its CMD in April 2018, Spire outlined its “2022 vision”, which targets £200m+ in EBITDA, 80% of sales from private patients and 100% of its hospitals rated good/outstanding by CQC. Six months later, it is increasingly clear to us that the 2022 targets are challenging and timelines are likely to slip. Self-pay, a key component of Spire’s 2022 targets, while growing high s.d. is well below the company’s target of 14% CAGR and we see little reason for this to change given lack of presence in Central London (c. 40% of the UK private market) and recent capex cuts. The NHS and PMI segments are also lagging. The NHS business in particular has seen substantial declines in local contract work and e-referrals given forecast flat budget spending in coming years. At PMI, high concentration of insurers and looming Brexit are unhelpful.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Our 2022E EBITDA is 20% below guidance: We take a more cautious view on each of the three payer segments at Spire, which results in our 2022 Revenue and EBITDA forecasts being 10% and 22% below company’s guidance respectively. We also see a risk of near-term downgrades, given the ongoing challenging environment at the NHS and our view of targeted cost savings being unable to compensate rising wage costs, shortages of skilled staff and escalating rents.

BE12:00pm

........ though they're buyers of Mediclinic.

Mediclinic International PLC (MDC:LSE): Last: 445.20, down 4.1 (-0.91%), High: 449.80, Low: 430.70, Volume: 2.48m
12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

Switzerland more than in the price, they say.

BE12:01pm

We update EPS to incorporate accretive Geneva deal and Spire minority stake. Our analysis reveals the market is overly pessimistic on Switzerland, where expanded Geneva presence boosts margins while the new swiss CEO should help deliver on 2020 targets. With Dubai Parkview hospital now opened, Middle East is poised for growth. Our revised PT to 564p implies 30% upside. Reiterate Buy.

Excel Developer what does CTA stand for , is it a momemtum player, Commodity Trading Adviser?
Excel Developer Computerised trading Account?
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian "Get the drop in ahead of the staff and hope they'll hold on for a while longer is the jist..." - why would you worry about them 'holding on'?
GBKrona thanks @BE, ROTR - slow week!
12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

And that's midday ..... but DFS, the retailer of some bracingly ugly sofas, was mentioned some time back.

DFS Furniture PLC (DFS:LSE): Last: 203.00, down 7 (-3.33%), High: 212.00, Low: 187.00, Volume: 948.13k
BE12:04pm

I've not looked to see why they're trading off, but I think the numbers are a tad weak.

Blank canvas thanks for everything today.
12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

Here's Stifel, which might be able to explain.

BE12:05pm

FY18 results are towards the lower end of expectations, reflecting a difficult season for indoor furniture retailers. The highlights today are much better than expected underlying cash generation, a maintained dividend (5.3% yield) and reaffirmed FY19 estimates early into the year. After two busy years for the group, against a difficult consumer backdrop, we look forward to a return to growth in the current year.

VV75 they are very weak
BE12:05pm

Key Points
Results: DFS has reported FY18 PBT of £38.3m (consensus c.£41m, Stifel £38.1m). Slightly low end of EBITDA guidance range indicated with the pre-close statement back in July. The soft performance reflects the impact of the unusually hot summer, and subdued consumer confidence, combined with port disruption at Felixstowe.

FY DPS of 11.2p unchanged YoY as expected (yield 5.3%).

Net debt: Much better than expected at £159m (Stifel £186.6m), despite the acquisition of Sofology, reflecting lower capex and much better working capital.

Management transition: Experienced COO Tim Stacey replaces CEO Ian Filby on November 1.

FY19 outlook: 9 weeks into the new year, LFL sales are ahead across the business, partly due to the benefit of purchases deferred over the summer. Nevertheless management expect to outperform a challenging market.

Valuation: At this stage management are comfortable with c.£50m consensus PBT for FY19, which is better than feared. This would represent a useful turnaround after two difficult years, helped by Sofology. The valuation - 11.7x P/E with a 5.3% dividend yield - represents a small sector discount.

Excel Developer "continued selling by trend following funds/ CTAs and a much stronger payrolls report" is the surrounding text to give context.
12:05 pm
